feature.title: Metabolic Medicine & Osteoporosis
feature.body: RNOH has one of the largest services in the world for the research and treatment of osteoporosis for men and woman as well as adolescents and adults with inherited metabolic diseases. The Unit provides specialist medical, dietetic and nursing advice to support treatment and education of patients.

content.title: Osteoporosis
content.body: Osteoporosis occurs when bones lose an excessive amount of their protein and mineral content, in particular calcium decreasing bone mass and bone strength over time. As a result bones become fragile and break easily. It is often called the “silent” disease, because bone loss occurs without symptoms.

content.title: Metabolic Bone Disease
content.body: Metabolic bone disease is an umbrella term referring to abnormalities of bones caused by a broad spectrum of disorders. Most commonly these disorders are caused by abnormalities of minerals such as calcium, phosphorus, magnesium or vitamin D leading to dramatic clinical disorders that are commonly reversible once the underlying defect has been treated.

content.title: Treatment & Rehabilitation
content.body: Therapy teams can prescribe appropriate exercises which are often a used to enhance and maintain good bone strength. Rehabilitation can also be geared towards helping manage some of the pain that can be associated with metabolic disorders as well as improving function.

content.title: Intravenous Therapies
content.body: Bone Densitometry Bone densitometry is a test like an X-ray that quickly and accurately measures the density of bone. It is used primarily to detect osteopenia or osteoporosis, diseases in which the bone's mineral and density are low and the risk of fractures is increased.
